deliberation: I checked the imperatives and nouns for figurative use. Found an idiomatic bodily expression for loud proclamation, an explicit simile comparing the prophet’s voice to a shofar, and a metonymic designation “house of Jacob” for the people.

instances.english_text: Cry with full throat, without restraint
target: The prophet’s proclamation of Israel’s sin
vehicle: Using the throat at full capacity
posture: Urgent, emphatic summons to speak out
instances.explanation: The phrase “cry with full throat” is an idiomatic way of saying ‘cry out loudly and fully’; the throat stands for the whole vocal power (synecdoche/idiom) and portrays an unrestrained proclamation.

instances.english_text: Raise your voice like a ram’s horn!
target: The prophet’s voice in announcing judgment
vehicle: The sounding of a shofar (ram’s horn)
ground: Piercing volume, clarity, capacity to summon and warn
posture: Directive to make the warning unmistakable
instances.explanation: An explicit simile: the prophet’s voice is to resemble a shofar blast in loudness and urgency, conveying a call to attention and alarm.

instances.english_text: To the House of Jacob
vehicle: “House of Jacob” as a familial household
ground: Descent from Jacob as defining identity
posture: Direct address to the covenant family
instances.explanation: “House of Jacob” is a metonymy (and familial metaphor) for the nation descended from Jacob, highlighting their shared lineage and covenant identity.

deliberation: I looked for path and spatial imagery, comparison markers, and ironic tone. Detected an ironic simile (“like a nation that does right”), plus two conceptual metaphors: God’s ‘ways’ as paths (conduct) and ‘nearness of God’ as spatial proximity for relational favor.

instances.english_text: Like a nation that does what is right
target: Hypocritical Israel engaged in pious-seeming practices
vehicle: A genuinely righteous nation that practices justice
ground: Outward appearance of diligent piety and seeking God
surface similarity in acts of devotion
instances.explanation: An explicit simile: Israel behaves as if it were a righteous nation, but the context shows this likeness is only superficial, making the comparison ironic.

instances.english_text: They are eager to learn My ways
target: God’s will and prescribed patterns of life
ground: A course of behavior is like a path one follows
posture: Acknowledges their professed eagerness while questioning its reality
instances.explanation: God’s ‘ways’ are not literal roads but a metaphor for His will and prescribed conduct; walking or learning ‘ways’ depicts adopting a manner of life.

instances.english_text: They are eager for the nearness of God
target: Experiencing God’s favor, presence, and approval
ground: Relational intimacy conceived as spatial nearness
posture: Exposes their desire for benefits of intimacy with God
instances.explanation: ‘Nearness of God’ uses spatial language metaphorically for relational and covenantal intimacy with God, not physical distance.

deliberation: Most of the verse describes literal fasting and economic oppression. I focused on the self-description “we afflicted our soul,” where נפש (soul) functions as synecdoche for the whole person and forms an idiomatic expression for self-denial.

instances.english_text: We starved our bodies (lit. “we afflicted our soul”)
target: Their whole selves undergoing fasting and discomfort
vehicle: נֶפֶשׁ (soul/life) as the seat of feeling
ground: The inner ‘soul’ stands for the entire self experiencing hardship
posture: Quoted complaint that overstates their piety
instances.explanation: The idiom ‘afflict our soul’ uses ‘soul’ as a synecdoche for the whole person, depicting fasting as an inwardly felt self-affliction, not literal injury to an immaterial entity.

deliberation: I examined whether ‘fasting in strife’ is figurative or simply descriptive, and focused on the clause about making their voice heard ‘on high,’ where ‘on high’ stands for heaven/God and being ‘heard’ stands for accepted prayer.

instances.english_text: To make your voice heard on high
target: Their prayers being noticed and favorably received by God
vehicle: A voice audible up in the heights of heaven
ground: Being ‘heard’ equates to gaining attention and response
height symbolizes God’s dwelling and transcendence
posture: Denies that their present fasting has this effect
instances.explanation: “On high” is a metonymy for heaven/God, and to have one’s voice ‘heard’ there is a metaphorical idiom for effective, accepted prayer, not a literal acoustic event.

deliberation: I noted ritual elements that can be literal (sackcloth, ashes) but function symbolically, and the explicit comparison of bowing the head to a bulrush. I treated the bulrush comparison as a simile and the sackcloth/ashes as metonymic for mourning/repentance.

instances.english_text: Is it bowing the head like a bulrush
ground: Downward bend, limp and dejected appearance
visual sign of being weighed down
posture: Questioning the sufficiency of mere outward show
instances.explanation: An explicit simile compares the bowed human head to a bent bulrush, highlighting outward dejection and implying that such mere posture is not the fast God desires.

instances.english_text: And lying in sackcloth and ashes
target: The state of mourning/repentance they claim to exhibit
vehicle: Wearing sackcloth and sitting/lying in ashes
ground: Outward symbols conventionally associated with grief and humiliation
posture: Ironically questions whether this outward display equals a true fast
instances.explanation: Sackcloth and ashes function metonymically and idiomatically for mourning and repentance; the physical actions symbolize and stand for an inner disposition that may actually be lacking.

deliberation: I looked at the cluster of ‘fetters,’ ‘cords,’ and ‘yoke’ terms. These are physical bondage images applied to social injustice and exploitation. I treated each distinct phrase as a separate metaphor within the shared conceptual metaphor ‘oppression is bondage.’

instances.english_text: To unlock fetters of wickedness
target: Systems and acts of injustice that bind people
vehicle: restraints used on prisoners or slaves
ground: Restriction of freedom, painful constraint, enforced immobility
instances.explanation: Wickedness is portrayed as ‘fetters’ that bind people, a metaphor turning moral and social injustice into physical chains that must be unlocked.

instances.english_text: And untie the cords of the yoke
target: Oppressive burdens placed on people (legal, economic, social)
vehicle: Cords and yoke used on draft animals
posture: Urges freeing others from imposed burdens
instances.explanation: The ‘yoke’ and its cords metaphorically depict oppressive demands and controls on people, as if they were beasts of burden that must be loosed.

instances.english_text: And break off every yoke
ground: Total removal of instruments of control
instances.explanation: ‘Every yoke’ is a metaphor for every kind of oppressive burden; to ‘break’ them is to abolish such domination, not merely lighten it.

deliberation: Most commands here are straightforward (share bread, house the homeless, clothe the naked). The key figurative element is ‘your own flesh’ for close kin or fellow humans, functioning as a metonymic/synecdochic designation.

instances.english_text: And not to ignore your own kin (lit. “your own flesh”)
target: One’s relatives and, by extension, fellow Israelites/humans
ground: Shared flesh symbolizes close relatedness and solidarity
bodily unity as image of social obligation
posture: Exhortation to show practical solidarity, not indifference
instances.explanation: ‘Your flesh’ stands metonymically and as synecdoche for relatives or fellow humans, expressing that those in need are as one’s own body and must not be ignored.

deliberation: This verse is rich in imagery. I identified: (1) a light/dawn simile and metaphor for salvation; (2) healing that ‘sprouts’ like a plant; (3) righteousness personified as marching ahead; and (4) the glory of YHWH personified as rear guard gathering/protecting.

instances.english_text: Then shall your light burst through like the dawn
target: Their restored condition—salvation, vindication, and well-being
vehicle: Light of dawn breaking through darkness
ground: Sudden, visible transition from darkness to light, from distress to relief
instances.explanation: ‘Your light’ is a metaphor for salvation and renewed favor; its bursting forth ‘like the dawn’ is an explicit simile evoking the sudden, hopeful arrival of daylight after darkness.

instances.english_text: And your healing shall spring up quickly
target: Their recovery from affliction (physical, social, spiritual)
ground: Healing conceived as upward, visible growth from hidden roots
instances.explanation: Healing is metaphorically depicted as a plant that ‘springs up,’ emphasizing organic, vigorous, and swift restoration.

instances.english_text: Your Vindicator (lit. “your righteousness”) shall march before you
target: Their righteousness and the vindicating effect of just conduct
vehicle: A leader or guard marching ahead in a procession or journey
ground: Righteousness providing protection and guidance like a leader at the front
posture: Portrays righteousness as an active, protective force
instances.explanation: Their ‘righteousness’ is personified as one who walks before them, a metaphor of a leading guard or guide that secures their way and vindicates them.

instances.english_text: The Presence (glory) of GOD shall be your rear guard
target: YHWH’s protective, manifest presence surrounding the people
vehicle: A rear guard gathering and protecting a group from behind
ground: Guarding, enclosing, and securing the vulnerable rear
posture: Strong promise of God’s protective involvement
instances.explanation: The ‘glory of YHWH’ (a metonymy for God’s manifest presence) is personified as a rear guard that gathers and protects the people from behind.

deliberation: The call-and-answer language is straightforward. I focused on the ethical conditions: the ‘yoke’ removed from their midst as metaphor for oppression, and the ‘pointing of the finger’ as an idiomatic metonymy for accusatory/oppressive gestures.

instances.english_text: If you banish the yoke from your midst
target: Oppressive practices and structures within the community
vehicle: A yoke set on animals for labor
ground: Oppression weighs down and controls like a yoke on the neck
instances.explanation: The ‘yoke’ is a metaphor for internal community oppression and burdens imposed on others; removing it means ending exploitative practices.

instances.english_text: The menacing hand (lit. “the sending of the finger”)
target: Accusatory, shaming, or threatening behavior toward others
vehicle: Pointing or thrusting a finger at someone
ground: A pointed finger symbolizes accusation, contempt, or intimidation
posture: Condemns hostile, demeaning treatment of others
instances.explanation: ‘Sending the finger’ is an idiomatic, metonymic expression: the gesture (finger) stands for accusatory and oppressive attitudes and actions.

deliberation: I distinguished between the inner ‘soul’ language—where נפש stands for the whole self/compassion—and the light/darkness imagery. I treated ‘pouring out your soul’ and ‘satisfy the famished soul’ as related soul-metaphors, and ‘your light in darkness / gloom like noonday’ as a second imagery cluster.

instances.hebrew_text: וְתָפֵק לָרָעֵב נַפְשֶׁךָ וְנֶפֶשׁ נַעֲנָה תַּשְׂבִּיעַ
instances.english_text: And you offer your compassion to the hungry (lit. “draw out your soul to the hungry”) and satisfy the famished soul
target: Their inner resources of compassion and practical care
vehicle: Drawing out and satisfying the ‘soul’ as an internal entity
ground: The inner life (נפש) represents the whole person and emotional energy; helping is like pouring out and filling souls
hunger as need, satisfaction as relief
posture: Commends deep, heartfelt generosity, not mere token aid
instances.explanation: ‘Draw out your soul’ and ‘satisfy the famished soul’ are idiomatic metaphors where ‘soul’ stands for the whole person/inner compassion, and human need is depicted as soul-hunger that can be filled.

instances.english_text: Then shall your light shine in darkness, and your gloom shall be like noonday
target: Their situation of distress versus subsequent restoration and joy
vehicle: Light shining in darkness; gloom transformed into the brightness of noon
ground: Deliverance and joy are like light; suffering and confusion are like darkness; noonday symbolizes maximal brightness and clarity
posture: Promises radical reversal of their condition upon practicing justice
instances.explanation: Light/darkness language is metaphorical for well-being vs. trouble, and the simile ‘your gloom like noonday’ intensifies the image of complete reversal from deepest shadow to brightest clarity.

deliberation: I saw (1) desert imagery for adversity and divine provision, (2) ‘bones’ representing physical and inner strength, and (3) two parallel similes: like a watered garden and like a spring whose waters do not fail. I treated these as three distinct figurative elements.

instances.english_text: Slaking your thirst in parched places (lit. “He will satisfy your soul in scorched places”)
target: Their life amid hardship and scarcity
vehicle: A scorched, waterless landscape being supplied with satisfaction
ground: Hardship is like a parched land, and God’s provision is like unexpected sustenance there
posture: Assures divine care even in extreme adversity
instances.explanation: Their ‘soul’ (life) in ‘scorched places’ is metaphorical desert imagery for severe adversity; God’s satisfying it is like watering a parched land.

instances.english_text: And giving strength to your bones
vehicle: Bones as the structural core of the body
ground: Bones represent foundational strength and health of the whole person
posture: Promises renewed strength at a deep, foundational level
instances.explanation: ‘Bones’ function metonymically/synecdochically for the person’s fundamental strength; to strengthen the bones is to renew comprehensive vitality.

instances.hebrew_text: וְהָיִיתָ כְּגַן רָוֶה וּכְמוֹצָא מַיִם אֲשֶׁר לֹא־יְכַזְּבוּ מֵימָיו
instances.english_text: You shall be like a watered garden, like a spring whose waters do not fail
target: The community’s flourishing and fruitfulness under God’s care
vehicle: A well-irrigated garden; an unfailing spring of water
lush cultivated space; reliable water source
posture: Offers an attractive picture of sustained flourishing
instances.explanation: Two explicit similes liken the restored community to a lush garden and a never-failing spring, evoking ongoing fertility, refreshment, and stability.

deliberation: The rebuilding of ruins and foundations can be literal, but the honorific titles at the end—“repairer of the breach” and “restorer of paths to dwell in”—use architectural/urban images for social and covenantal restoration. I treated these two epithets as distinct metaphors.

instances.english_text: Repairer of fallen walls (lit. “repairer of the breach”)
target: Those who restore social and covenantal integrity
vehicle: Someone who repairs a breach in a city wall
ground: Healing divisions and vulnerabilities is like mending a broken wall
posture: Highly honorific designation for agents of repair
instances.explanation: ‘Repairer of the breach’ is a metaphorical title: community healers are likened to builders who close gaps in a wall, restoring protection and wholeness.

instances.english_text: Restorer of lanes for habitation
target: Those who reestablish viable communal life and access
vehicle: Restoring pathways/roads so that people can dwell and travel securely
ground: Reopening ways for movement and settlement parallels restoring conditions for stable communal life
posture: Honors the work of reestablishing thriving community structures
instances.explanation: The title ‘restorer of paths to dwell in’ metaphorically depicts those who rebuild the social and spiritual infrastructure as people who make roads and neighborhoods livable again.

deliberation: I examined the expressions around Sabbath observance. The key figurative element is ‘turning back your foot from the Sabbath,’ where the foot stands for conduct and ‘treading’ the Sabbath pictures profaning it. The rest of the phrases (your ways, your affairs) are conventional path/affair language but less pronounced here.

instances.english_text: If you refrain from trampling the sabbath (lit. “turn back your foot from the sabbath”)
target: Their behavior that would profane or misuse the Sabbath
vehicle: A foot stepping on or trampling something
ground: Profaning the day is like stepping on it; refraining is like withdrawing one’s foot
posture: Exhortation to treat the Sabbath with reverent restraint
instances.explanation: The ‘foot’ stands metonymically for one’s conduct, and ‘turning it back from the Sabbath’ is an idiomatic metaphor for ceasing to trample or misuse the holy day.

deliberation: I noted three distinct promise images: (1) delighting oneself ‘on YHWH’ as metaphor for relational joy, (2) riding on the heights of the earth as metaphor (and perhaps hyperbole) for exalted security and dominion, and (3) being fed with Jacob’s heritage as metaphor for fully enjoying covenant blessings.

instances.english_text: Then you can seek GOD’s favor (lit. “you shall delight yourself on YHWH”)
target: Israel’s relationship with YHWH and experience of Him
vehicle: Taking exquisite delight in something delightful
ground: Relationship with God is conceived as a source of deep pleasure and joy
posture: Presents obedience as leading to genuine joy in God
instances.explanation: ‘Delight yourself on YHWH’ is an idiomatic metaphor in which God is the object of intense enjoyment, depicting the relationship as deeply pleasurable rather than burdensome.

instances.english_text: I will set you astride the heights of the earth
target: Israel’s exalted status, security, and dominion under God
vehicle: Riding on the high places of the land
ground: Being on the heights suggests sovereignty, safety from enemies, and honor
posture: Exalted and somewhat hyperbolic promise of triumph and honor
instances.explanation: To ride ‘on the heights of the earth’ is a metaphor (with hyperbolic flavor) for being lifted to a position of triumph, security, and prominence.

instances.english_text: And let you enjoy the heritage of your father Jacob (lit. “I will feed you the heritage of Jacob your father”)
target: Israel’s full enjoyment of the ancestral promises (land, blessing)
ground: Enjoying promised blessings is like being fed with rich food
posture: Assures tangible enjoyment of covenant benefits
instances.explanation: The ‘heritage of Jacob’ (metonymy for covenant promises) is portrayed as food God will ‘feed’ them, a metaphor for richly partaking in and being satisfied by those promises.
